content:
Well, I got 100% on all tests and 75% on submission, as so often happens.
It was, of course, validator 1, and I didn't bother to round up when dividing. It would have made sense to round up, but when I passed all tests, I simply submitted the code. Mayyybe it would be appropriate to have a test case that depends on rounding up?
CG puzzles usually state that, if code passes a test, it will also pass that validator...

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun, rather simple CoC puzzle, don't really see the reason for * all around the bar, but they cool aspect I suppose!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's a fun and easy to understand challenge. I like it!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Rather unusual task

I would suggest changing name of the [[m]] variable to [[p]], because it's pause time.
And changing Goal description to:

Given [[l]] length of the song and [[p]] the time when the song was paused (both in <<mm:ss>> format), you need to print the song's progress bar with already passed time intervals.
Max progress bar length is {{15}}, each time interval is represented by "-".
Also the bar should be surrounded by "*", as you can see it in the example.

Seems to me this clash is a variation of the progress bar clash, which we already have, but I suppose the addition of the time element makes it different enough.
I am no English expert but the term "Music Bar" was confusing to me as I thought you were talking about a bar as in a measure like in sheet music. Perhaps you should change it to something less ambiguous.
"An ASCII music bar stopped at the minute m." should be probably "stopped at time m".
Also please specify what kind of rounding is expected.

i appreciate your answer its also very helpful to me, so as it s my first contribution i normally do multiple mistakes, but when we get a great community as well as you we can easily improve and help each other. Thank you again, and i hope doing better next time. By the way i did some changes like you told me.
Thank you for your response, you were very helpful ! Also, I did the changes you suggested to me.

I know almost no python but it seems to me the author is actually using floor in his solution.
Regardless, as I've said in my first comment one should not have to guess what type of rounding is expected.
I thought the contribution would have been updated before getting accepted but apparently not.

Well, my code actually divided the entire length by 15, and divided the pause point by that. For test 1, it gave :
222//15 = 14
49//14 = 3 (correct)

For validator 1:
293//15 = 19
250//19 = 13 (incorrect)

The floor vs. rounding got me on the first part.
Like I said, it was not the best way to do it, but I was rushing, and it passed all tests with 100%.
